Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Tailoring Energy Flow in Magnetic Oscillator Arrays

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project seeks to develop an integrated research and educational collaboration to examine the fundamental behavior of large arrays of coupled nonlinear oscillators. Through a combined series of theoretical and experimental investigations, we will investigate how alterations in the coupling (via magnetic interactions) can tailor bandgaps, bifurcations, the localization of energy, and a new phenomena called a passively reconfiguring bandgap. Research studies build from theory to micro/macro experimental demonstrations with a focus on tuning the magnetic interactions to create desired phenomena. The Principle Investigators believe the passively reconfiguring bandgaps, where a response threshold could be used to completely reconfigure the bandgap structure, offers a fundamentally new capability for avoiding catastrophic failures.

The fundamental nature of the research investigations is expected to improve engineering practice with specific examples of how to exploit nonlinearity to achieve desirable energy flow behaviors in oscillator arrays. The avoidance of catastrophic failures from mechanical or acoustic overloads is a specific application area for this research. Educational and outreach efforts will leverage the PIs successful involvement in existing programs, the Pratt Fellows program at Duke University and the NSF funded Southeast Alliance for Graduate Education and the Professoriate (SEAGEP) program at the University of Florida, to attract underrepresented students to participate in engineering research and pursue advanced degrees. Summertime graduate student exchanges are planned to broaden the perspectives of everyone involved and enhance the project collaboration and impact.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research pursued an ambitious research agenda with fundamentally new ideas on exploiting nonlinear phenomena in oscillator arrays. Research studies built from theory to micro/macro experimental demonstrations with a focus on tuning the magnetic interactions to create desired phenomena.  The idea of exploiting the nonlinear interactions to create bandgaps that passively reconfigure at a bifurcation point was one of the most transformative ideas within this proposal. The PIs believe the passively reconfiguring bandgaps, where a response threshold could be used to completely reconfigure the bandgap struc- ture, offers a fundamentally new capability for avoiding catastrophic failures from mechanical, electrical, or acoustic overloads. We envision many other potential applications for these structures, ranging from energy conversion systems to acoustic and vibration control. An additional exciting feature of this proposal was the fabrication and testing of large-scale arrays of microresonators since the experiments would enable experimental demonstration and numerical model validation. 

Educational and outreach efforts leveraged the PIs successful involvement in existing programs, the Pratt Fellows program at Duke and the NSF SEAGEP program at UF, to attract underrepresented students to participate in engineering research and pursue advanced degrees. Shor-term graduate student exchanges allowed the students involved in this research to broaden their perspectives, increase communications, and enhance the project collaboration and impact. It is beleived the fundamental nature of these  research investigations has enhanced the infrastructure for future research with enabling examples that showcase the ability to exploit nonlinearity to achieve desirable energy flow behaviors in oscillator arrays. The technical outcomes are of broad relevance to a myriad of scientific fields and this project has enabled students to collaborate with researchers beyond the halls of their academic institution.
